channel.title: 4A-GE 16V Bluetop Burning Oil
channel.description:
4A-GE 16V Bluetop Burning Oil
Suddenly, in the last few days, my car has started to burn oil. And from the exhaust it looks pretty bad. The car still seems to have full power though. Does anyone know what could be happening that is causing the motor to burn oil?
EDIT: I am starting to think it might be a broken head gasket. I will check the water level tomorrow morning.

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

As I said, blue smoke means it’s burning oil, which can be any of an entire list of reasons causing it. White smoke means it’s burning water, which means you have a blown head gasket. Depending on how/where it is blown, you could be losing oil too. Regardless you are going to have to fix it, and, unless you do it yourself, it isn’t going to be cheap.

item.title: 4A-GE 16V Bluetop Burning Oil
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

runescape3dude:

From what it looks like, I don’t think it is even really burning any much oil. But the water level has dropped rapidly and last night I left the car running for 5 mins and I could barely find it behind all the white smoke.

When a car burns oil it will put out BLUE smoke, WHITE smoke means you are burning water or anti-freeze. A little is alright when you start it because it is generally just some condensation, but if your water level dropped and steady white smoke is coming out only one thing is possible. You have a blown head gasket.

item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It could be the head gasket as you said, check the water for oil and vice-versa. But it is also probably bad valve seals, it’s not really that big of a deal if it’s not burning a lot of oil (check it regularly though, like once a day). If you want it to stop smoking, like if you are going to sell it or something, you could change the oil to full synthetic, because it doesn’t smoke. (but it’s much more expensive, so you don’t want to run it if it’s burning oil)

item.title: 4A-GE 16V Bluetop Burning Oil
item.dc:creator: @Innovation Innovation
item.description:
@Innovation wrote:

Don’t know if this is your case but here’s what I found

(http://www.newcarbuyingguide.com/index.php/news/main/840/event=view)
1. Bad valve seals
2. Worn valve guides
3. Pressurized crankcase (oil pan) due to a clogged PCV valve or breather system
4. Blow-by from worn piston rings

And surprisingly yahoo answers… (http://answers.yahoo.com/question/index?qid=20091230135616AAVQRqF)

Best Answer - Chosen by Voters Cam, rod or main bearings have absolutely no "bearing" on why your motor uses oil. If the bearings were bad the crankshaft would be laying in your driveway or a connecting rod would be a new part sticking through the side of your block.

If the motor has no visible external leaks, the only other possibilities are worn piston rings, plugged up oil rings, worn cylinder bores or worn valve guides. The areas I’ve listed allow excess crankcase oil to enter the combustion chamber to be burned.

Causes are directly related to a forgetful oil change maintenance schedule or an engine with a thermostat stuck open. What kind of oil do you use? What viscosity is it? How often do you have it changed? Does your heater kick out high temperature heat once the motor has warmed up?
Source(s):
Alignment, suspension and brake shop.
